授業目的: This course is a continuation of our exploration of cross‑cultural communication. It deepens students’ understanding of English pragmatics by examining communication styles such as direct versus indirect approaches and politeness strategies across cultures. Students will investigate authentic texts, academic articles, and case studies to understand how language shapes and is shaped by cultural expectations. Throughout the semester, learners will conduct a research project and report the findings of their research, integrating theoretical insights with practical observations.
到達目標: By the end of the course, students will be able to:1. Analyze English Pragmatics: Explain key pragmatic concepts such as speech acts, implicature, and context, and evaluate their role in intercultural communication.2. Compare Communication Styles: Identify and compare direct and indirect communication approaches, discussing how these strategies are employed in Japanese, Western, and other cultural contexts.3. Evaluate Politeness Strategies: Critically examine theories of politeness and assess how these strategies function in various communication scenarios.4. Integrate Theory and Practice: Combine insights from pragmatic theory with real-world case studies to deepen understanding of cultural communication dynamics.5. Conduct and Report Research: Design and execute a research project on topics related to English pragmatics and cultural communication, and effectively report the findings of that research.
授業方法: Classes are conducted face-to-face in the classroom.

第1回: Course Introduction & Overview• Review of cross‑cultural communication• Introduction to English pragmatics and cultural styles
第2回: Group Discussion. In this session, you will share your ideas about how culture affects communication.
第3回: Basics of English Pragmatics. You will learn key ideas such as speech acts and hints in conversation, and why context is important.
第4回: You will talk about examples of pragmatics in daily life.
第5回: Direct vs. Indirect Communication. You will learn what direct and indirect communication are and see examples from different cultures.
第6回: You will compare and contrast direct and indirect communication, discussing the benefits and challenges of each style. Homework: Share your examples and opinions during the discussion.
第7回: Politeness Theories. You will review simple ideas about politeness, including basic theories such as those by Brown and Levinson.
第8回: Group Discussion. You will talk about how politeness works in different settings, such as at school or in everyday life.
第9回: Combining Pragmatics and Culture. You will examine a case study that shows how culture affects communication, including problems and successes.
第10回: You will share your research ideas and discuss different methods with your peers. Homework: Bring your research question ideas to the discussion.
第11回: Research Methods for Pragmatics & Culture. You will learn simple research methods used in language studies and begin to think about your own research questions.
第12回: You will share your research ideas and discuss different methods with your peers
第13回: Planning Your Research. You will start planning your research project by designing your research framework and outlining your project.
第14回: Group Discussion. You will discuss your research plans and get feedback from your classmates.
第15回: Digital Communication and Social Media. You will learn how digital tools and social media influence cross‑cultural communication.
第16回: Discuss the role of digital media in communication and share your ideas about its impact on cultural interactions.
第17回: Communication in Professional and Academic Settings. You will study how communication works in global business and educational environments, including challenges and best practices.
第18回: WRITING - Thesis Statement, Body Paragraph 1 + 2 + 3 + introduction + conclusion
トピック.授業計画1:
Lessons held in the computer lab will be focused on research and writing for the final essay and presentation. Lessons held in normal classrooms will be for lectures, group discussions, and textbook activities.
Skills that will be highlighted in this course:
Writing an argumentative/persuasive essay that argues for one side of a global issue;
synthesizing information; quoting, paraphrasing, and summarizing, supporting opinions with facts and statistics, critical thinking, research skills, basic APA citation format, avoiding plagiarism, gathering data through field research
トピック.授業外学習2: Students must be highly motivated to succeed in this course. The will need to research, read, and prepare discussions for authentic English texts outside of class. Students must also work on their own research papers for homework.
